children.subject: Hi Jake, thanks for your message. I will probably ping you with more questions about sorting out research soon, as an undergraduate at Berkeley talking to another person who went to Berkeley for undergrad looking for general advice on how to proceed. Note that this fall I've been doing more poorly than usual (as is everyone), and realized I don't really have that much sorted out. I think fall is critical for research progress, but some of it was out of my control too as I still am in a learning process. Therefore, I don't think it's my mentor's fault, but would like to have a more informed opinion from someone who went to Berkeley as an undergrad about how to do things

Here's my 2 cents for what it's worth. For background, I'm currently a grad student who did their undergraduate at Berkeley in CS, worked on research as an undergrad, am currently working on research, hoping to get some publications, and mentoring undergraduates.

1. You sound like you are doing really great and in your academic career so far. Getting mostly As, double majoring in applied math, and having 1+ years of research experience as a junior is extremely impressive. It is great preparation for graduate school (either the 5th year masters or a PhD). Better than what most people you would be competing with for grad school get.

2. That's unfortunate that your mentor ('sort of' to quote you) discouraged you from applying to graduate school. A mentor should really just not do that. A mentor should also not tell you that they would not write a good letter of recommendation for you. They are supposed to be your advocate, not your detractor. If they are saying these things to you, it is inappropriate, disrespectful, and unprofessional and you should take that up with someone higher up in your lab. Your work/research environment should be about the work, not stress over your relationship with your mentor/supervisor. You sound like an extremely well qualified candidate and will definitely end up somewhere amazing for grad school. Regardless of whatever one person's opinion is.

3. It sounds to me like there was/is some kind of miscommunication between you and this graduate student. These kinds of miscommunications are common in any professional context and it is important for your professional development to learn how to address them. Miscommunications can really only be fixed by having honest conversations about what you are capable of doing in terms of your skills and time availability and about what your goals are for your research experience at Berkeley. Frankness and directness tempered with respect is your best way forward. If you feel like you can address your problems directly with your mentor, do that. If you feel like you want to talk about this to someone higher up in your lab like a faculty member, do that. If you think all of this is a lost cause, I'm sure another lab would take you in a heartbeat seeing how experienced you are.

4. Finally, don't give into imposter syndrome. A lot of Berkeley students deal with it. If you are at Berkeley and working at a prestigious lab, its because you work hard enough and are smart enough to be there. You're not just faking it. I promise.

Happy to answer any other questions here or if you want to email me, ping me at jakemtibbetts@berkeley.edu

Regarding the other undergrad and the grad school situation: yes, and this is also my understanding of the situation. However, the mentor also asked me if I was shooting for top 10 or top 20. Something like that... (and maybe this is even after I do a fifth year masters)
I feel like the fall semester has influenced a lot of my own plans wrt a potential grad school. I feel like if fall went more smoothly, I would be more certain about a future plan that would set me on track. I'll sort this out and take your and Jake's suggestions

Also my two cents as a former Berkeley CS undergrad who's now doing grad school.

First of all, don't worry about the learning curve as long as you are putting forth an honest effort with a reasonable amount of time towards research (I'd usually say around 10-20 hours a week but that really depends). When I just started doing research as an undergrad, I did things wrong more often than I did things right; you are just in the unlucky position of being compared to somebody who gets things wrong less often than you do.

However I would want to clarify one of the points being made by the other response: your research mentor wasn't saying that you shouldn't apply to grad school, what I think they were saying is that if you are applying to grad school at the same time as this other undergrad, your application won't be looked at as favorably as theirs because you have similar backgrounds and research interests, except their performance was better than yours. While this is true, the aforementioned other person can only go to one grad program, so I doubt it would huge difference unless you are dead set on going to a top 4 program.

history.content:
I'm a third year who is doing research. My background is starting research in sophomore year (fall 2019) to do a ML project from URAP, followed by some lighter research involving neural networks in spring 2020.  

I'm in a reputable lab this semester (which I will not name for anonymity), but a lab that doesn't take many undergrads, (edit: and it is my first time doing real research underneath a phd student). I got sometimes stuck last semester due to 1) some gaps in knowledge for pytorch, 2) I was doing somewhat badly in one of my classes and had to study hard for the final to perform a clobber, and also 3) didn't really know much of what I was doing the past semester. (edit: I took a break from late November - December). I've finished learning pytorch very thoroughly over break. However, while the plan is to publish in May/June, I feel like the PhD student I work with isn't (edit: 100%) confident in me. He said that he is working with another undergrad and wants to get publications out with him in February/March. Then he also told me that I should keep his weekly meetings but I'm pretty discouraged and afraid that publication won't work. He also sort of said I hope you and the aforementioned undergrad don't apply to PhD at the same time because the other undergrad is very advanced(and he is -- he's (edit) worked on advanced stuff since high school, but the undergraduate is clearly advanced and is taking like 4-5 technicals / semester which not every standard student in research does, and that shouldn't affect me) and the rec letters would be really different just because of the undergraduate's experience. I just want to do research and do things on time, too. 

This isn't really his fault either because there are learning curves in research and maybe I'm not directly taught everything because everything's online, and he was not a Berkeley undergrad and he thinks I should take my time. But I'm actually, like, scared because third years at Berkeley rn typically learn or are taught things during research. I'm not sure what learning curve I have to overcome.

I'm really stressed out because the expectation around me I feel is to have some sort of result out by spring or that I knew about conferences and plans around that. Like my friends are sort of asking me what type of research I've been doing and I feel like I have nothing to say. But it's hard to tell the phd student this directly. And while this might be the fault of me not immediately knowing I would want to do a PhD right after college, and also the fault of doing research online I still think people just standardly go with the flow and do research as an extracurricular for fifth year masters or whatever, and expect to get taught well in research.

If there's any advice I can get now, going into spring semester, to overcome my own learning curve in research? What is the best way to learn? And tbh my plans are looking like fifth year masters before applying to PhD, and the PhD student did mention the fifth year masters program as an avenue and this is probably the avenue I'll take. I would've thought about grad school if I did more last semester or planned better.

My CS track looks like mostly As in classes and am taking 189, a grad class, and either another ML class or a math upper div, willing to cut classes for productive research. doubling in applied math cs, taking 4 years.

Update: it is hard to get hand-holding mentorship from a grad student so this is something to take into account when putting the paragraph above in context, but I am still struggling with learning curve. and I'm not sure of general timelines

Update: I made some edits to the post to redact specific information and to include some more contextual info

I'm really stressed out because the expectation around me I feel is to have some sort of result out by spring or that I knew a lot about conferences. Like my friends are sort of asking me what type of research I've been doing and I feel like I have nothing to say. But it's hard to tell him this directly so idk? And while this might be the fault of me not immediately knowing I would want to do a PhD right after college, and also the fault of doing research online I still think people just standardly go with the flow and do research as an extracurricular for fifth year masters or whatever, and expect to get taught well in research.

If there's any advice I can get now, going into spring semester? And tbh my plans are looking like fifth year masters before applying to PhD, and the PhD student did mention the fifth year masters program as an avenue

My CS track looks like mostly As in classes and am taking 189, a grad class, and either another ML class or a math upper div, willing to cut classes for productive research. doubling in applied math cs, taking 4 years.
